title: The Case of the Missing Heiress
description: Lady Victoria Blackwood, a wealthy heiress, has been found dead in her locked study. The cause appears to be poisoning, but who among her household had motive and opportunity?

characters.name: James the Butler
characters.description: The loyal family butler who has served the Blackwood family for 30 years.
characters.publicInfo: Has been with the family for decades and knows all their secrets. Recently seemed worried about something.
characters.privateInfo: You discovered Lady Blackwood was planning to fire you and replace you with a younger butler. You have gambling debts that Lady Blackwood recently discovered. You've been stealing small amounts from the household budget to pay your debts.
secrets: You have been stealing small amounts of money from the household budget to pay gambling debts.
You overheard Lady Blackwood on the phone with an employment agency last week discussing your replacement.
You owe £15,000 to dangerous people who have threatened violence if not paid soon.

relationships.char_secretary: You work closely together managing the household
relationships.char_gardener: You've noticed him acting strangely lately
relationships.char_maid: You've been training her and she looks up to you

characters.name: Richard Blackwood
characters.description: Lady Blackwood's nephew and potential heir to the fortune.

characters.privateInfo: You are deeply in debt and desperately need your inheritance. Lady Blackwood recently threatened to change her will after discovering you forged her signature on a check. You owe £50,000 to dangerous people.

You forged Lady Blackwood's signature on a check for £5,000 last month.

characters.name: Dr. Margaret Thornfield
characters.description: The family physician and Lady Blackwood's close friend.
characters.publicInfo: A respected doctor who has been treating the family for years. Very close to Lady Blackwood.
characters.privateInfo: You have been slowly poisoning Lady Blackwood with small doses of arsenic in her medication, planning to make it look like natural causes. You had an affair with her late husband and she was starting to suspect the truth about his death.
secrets: You have been having an affair with Lady Blackwood's late husband before he died.
You falsified medical records to cover up the real cause of Lord Blackwood's death - you poisoned him too.
You've been gradually increasing arsenic doses in Lady Blackwood's medication over the past month.

clues.title: Empty Poison Bottle
clues.content: A small glass bottle labeled 'Arsenic - For Pest Control' found hidden in the garden shed. The bottle is empty but has recent fingerprints on it. There are traces of white powder residue inside.

clues.title: Threatening Letter
clues.content: A letter found in Lady Blackwood's desk drawer: 'Pay what you owe or face the consequences. You have one week. We know where you live.' The handwriting appears to be disguised, written in block letters.

clues.title: Financial Discrepancies
clues.content: Bank statements showing irregular withdrawals and transfers over the past year. Several payments to unknown companies and cash withdrawals of large amounts. Total discrepancies amount to over £100,000.

clues.title: Medical Test Results
clues.content: Lady Blackwood's recent medical records show elevated levels of arsenic in her blood from tests taken last month. The levels were concerning but not immediately fatal. A note indicates 'patient complaining of stomach pains and fatigue.'

clues.title: Neighbor's Account
clues.content: Mrs. Henderson from the neighboring estate reported seeing someone in dark clothing leaving through the garden gate around midnight on the night of the murder. The figure appeared to be carrying something small.

clues.title: Suspicious Check
clues.content: A check made out for £5,000 with Lady Blackwood's signature, dated last month. However, handwriting analysis reveals the signature is a forgery. The check was cashed at a local bank.

clues.title: Hidden Safe Key
clues.content: A small key found hidden behind a loose brick in the garden wall. The key opens a safe in Lady Blackwood's study containing important documents including her will and adoption papers.

clues.title: Tampered Medication
clues.content: Lady Blackwood's heart medication bottle shows signs of tampering. The capsules have been opened and resealed. Chemical analysis reveals traces of arsenic mixed with the original medication.

solution.motive: To cover up her affair with Lord Blackwood and prevent Lady Blackwood from discovering she had been slowly poisoning her to steal her fortune.
solution.method: Arsenic poisoning administered through Lady Blackwood's heart medication over several weeks, with a final lethal dose given the night of her death.
solution.explanation: Dr. Margaret Thornfield had been having an affair with Lord Blackwood before his death, which she also caused through poisoning. When Lady Blackwood began to suspect the truth about her husband's death and threatened to change doctors, Dr. Thornfield began slowly poisoning Lady Blackwood with arsenic mixed into her heart medication. The plan was to make it appear as natural causes, but when Lady Blackwood's suspicions grew and she scheduled an appointment with a new doctor, Dr. Thornfield administered a final lethal dose. The doctor had access to the medication, knowledge of poisons, and the medical expertise to carry out the murder while initially avoiding suspicion. The empty arsenic bottle in the garden shed was planted to frame the gardener, but her fingerprints were still on it.
